bibl.title: Letter from Joseph Y. Porter to Howard A. Kelly, November 28, 1904

div1.p: Porter confesses he was only a general colleague of Walter Reed, so he is unable to provide much information for Kelly's biography of Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph Y. Porter to Howard A. Kelly, November 28, 1904
div1.opener:
Executive Office,
State Board of Health of Florida
Jacksonville, Fla., Nov. 28, 1904.
Joseph Y. Porter, M.D.
State Health Office
Personal
---78---
Dr. H. A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Kelly:-
div1.p:
I am just in receipt of your note of Nov. 21st.,
which I find on my desk after a few days absence, from the Office.

I regret that I cannot give you the information in regard to
Dr. Reed, as I have had but very little professional intercourse
with him. He was sent to Key West in 1896 to study smallpox--of
which I had a goodly number of cases among negroes. Whether he
anticipated Councilman or not I do not know, as he never did tell
me. He never gave me any inkling as to the results of his work.
He entered the Army just before I did--in '74--and I entered in
'75. It was only in this way--being in the same Corps, that I
can say that we were in any-wise acquainted professionally. He
was a most lovable man, a most modest man and a great seeker of
the truth, but not intrusive in his opinion or offensive in urg-
ing his claims. His death was certainly a great loss to the
Medical Profession as well as to his many personal friends.
